channel.title: Zumafi MD Part I Notes on ZDoc
channel.description: Recent content in Zumafi MD Part I Notes on ZDoc

item.title: 3 Important Zones
item.description: Three important zones of the upperlimb The axilla Zone of transition between neck and upperlimb Irregular tilted pyramid shape. Walls Anterior wall 2 layers Superficial layer is made up of Pec major Deep layer is made up of pac minor and subclavius and clavipectoral fascia. Posterior wall Longer wall. Above downwards made up succeessively Subscapularis Teres major Latissimus dorsi Medium wall Made up of Upper four intercostal spaces Digitations of serratus anterior.

item.title: Bones and Joints
item.description: Bones and joints of the upperlimb The scapula Triangular bone with 3 prominent features Lateral - Glenoid fossa Posterior - Spine projecting as acromion process Anterior - Coracoid process The clavicle An unusual long bone Most commonly fractured bone in the body. It has no medullary cavity. First bone to ossify (5th week of the fetus) Long bone, but develops in the membrane. (Not cartilage) Medial 2/3 Circular in section Convex anteriorly Lateral 1/3 Flatten in section Convex posteriorly Sternoclavicular joint The ball and socket joint moves reciprocally with shoulder joint movements around its fulcrum, costoclavicular ligament.

item.title: Brachial Plexus
item.description: Brachial plexus Structure of the brachial plexus Brachial plexus may damage during open or closed injuries, during child birth. It might be compressed by a cervical rib or may involve a tumor. It is formed by 5 roots from the anterior rami of C5 to T1 Structure 5 roots Roots lie between anterior and middle scalene muscles. 3 Trunks Roots link up to form 3 trunks Lie deep to facia of the posterior triangle of the neck Upper trunk is formed by C5 and C6 Middle trunk is formed by C7 Lower trunk is formed by C8 and T1 6 divisions Divisions lie behind clavical.

item.title: Surface Marking & Basics
item.description: Surface marking Bones and joints that can be palpated Clavicle Supraclavicular nerves Scapula Medial border Acromian process Coracoid process Scapular Spine Head of the humerus at the apex of axilla. Elbow Olecranon process Medial and lateral epicondyles Head of the radius Ulna posterior border Wrist Styloid process of radius Styloid process of ulnar Head of ulnar Dorsal tubercle of lister Palm Pisiform (FCU insertion point) Hook of hamate Scaphoid tubercle Muscles and tendons that can be palpated Anterior fold of axilla - Pactoralis major Posterior fold of axilla - Teres major, latissimus dorsi Medial axillary wall - Digitations of serratus anterior Radial border - Brachioradialis Radial pulse, FCR, PL, FDS, UA, FCU Anatomical snuff box - EPL, EPB and APL Extensor digitorum Superficial Veins Cephalic vein Drains from dorsal venous network of the hand Origin posterior to styloid process of the radius, in superifical fascia Runs up the anterior aspect of the forearm, then lies in a grove along the lateral border of the biceps.

item.title: Arteries
item.description: Arteries of the upperlimb The axillary artery Commences at the first rib. Ends at the lowerborder of the axilla. i.e Teres major. It has three parts. The three parts are divided by the overlying pectoralis minor muscle. Mostly covered by the pectoralis major muscle. Brachial plexus cords are named in relation to the axillary artery (distal to the pectoralis minor.) Branches of the axillary artery supplies the chest wall and the shoulder.
This article offers a sample of basic Markdown syntax that can be used in Hugo content files, also it shows whether basic HTML elements are decorated with CSS in a Hugo theme.

item.title: Cubital fossa
item.description: Cubital fossa Triangular area Boundaries Pronator teres Brachioradialis Line joining humeral epicondyles Roof - Deep fascia of forearm Floor Brachialis Supinator Contents (Medial to lateral) My Brother Throws Red Parties Median nerve Brachial artery Tendon of biceps Radial nerve + branch Posterior interosseous nerve Superficial branch of the radial nerve passes under brachioradialis - Not mentioned in the contents

item.title: Basics of lowerlimb
item.description: Basics of lower limb Bone What is the pectineal line? The pectineal line (pecten pubis) of the pubis is a ridge on the superior ramus of the pubic bone, it passes to the pubic tubercle as a continuation of the arcuate line. The pecten pubis forms part of the pelvic brim. Lying across it are fibers of the pectineal ligament and the proximal origin of the pectineus muscle.
